title: What Factors Influence Your Fluid Needs?

sections.content: We often hear the advice: “Drink eight glasses of water a day!” — but in reality, it’s not that simple. Scientists have long abandoned this universal rule in favor of a more flexible approach: everyone’s fluid needs are unique and depend on many factors.

sections.subtitle: Body size and individual traits
sections.content: Men usually drink more than women, simply because on average their bodies are larger and require more water. Age also plays a role: both children and older adults may not feel thirst as clearly, so it’s harder for them to “catch” the right moment to drink.

sections.subtitle: Physical activity
sections.content: If you run, go to the gym, or simply move a lot throughout the day, your fluid requirements are higher. During activity, we lose water through sweat, and it needs to be replenished. Otherwise, fatigue, dizziness, and even dehydration can occur.

sections.subtitle: Climate and temperature
sections.content: Hot weather accelerates sweating, and the body loses fluids faster. But in winter, needs can also increase: dry indoor air and temperature changes cause additional fluid loss as well.

sections.subtitle: Special conditions
sections.content: Pregnant and breastfeeding women require more water to support both themselves and their baby. Illness also makes a difference — especially with fever, vomiting, or diarrhea — the body loses fluids much faster, and replenishing them becomes crucial.

sections.subtitle: Diet
sections.content: Spicy and salty foods increase thirst: salt retains water in the body but at the same time stimulates the desire to drink more. The type of diet also matters — for example, a high-protein diet increases fluid requirements.

sections.subtitle: Not just water
sections.content: Around 20% of daily fluid intake comes from food — especially vegetables, fruits, and soups. Drinks count too: tea, coffee, milk. Modern research confirms that moderate caffeine intake does not dehydrate the body, so your morning cup of coffee definitely “counts.”

sections.subtitle: How to know if you’re drinking enough?
sections.content: The main guide is how you feel. If you rarely feel thirsty, have good energy, your skin isn’t overly dry, and your head doesn’t feel heavy — you’re probably drinking enough. But if you notice fatigue, dry mouth, or trouble focusing, it’s a sign to pour yourself a glass of water.

title: How Does Water Help Keep Your Brain in Shape?

sections.content: You’ve probably noticed that by the middle of the day, thoughts seem to slow down, focus slips away, and even simple tasks take more effort. Fatigue, stress, or lack of sleep may play a role, but there’s another factor we often overlook — not getting enough water.

sections.subtitle: Water as Fuel for the Brain
sections.content: We usually think about drinking water for healthy skin, digestion, or overall well-being. But water is also vital fuel for the brain. About 75% of its structure is made up of water, and even a slight imbalance can affect mental clarity, memory, and mood.

sections.subtitle: What Happens When Water Is Lacking
sections.content: A decrease in fluid levels as small as 1–2% can already influence cognitive performance. It doesn’t mean that a person becomes “less intelligent.” Rather, the brain, like any complex system, works best when everything is in balance. With too little water, it becomes harder to maintain focus, distraction increases, fatigue builds up faster, and irritability may appear without any obvious reason.

sections.subtitle: What Research Shows
sections.content: These effects have been documented in scientific studies. For example, a review published in The Journal of Nutrition (2012) found that even mild dehydration can slow down information processing, weaken short-term memory, and make concentration more difficult.

sections.subtitle: Why Thirst Is a Late Signal
sections.content: The brain reacts to water shortage even before you feel thirsty. By the time the body sends the “I need water” signal, it has already been working below its optimal state.

sections.subtitle: What This Means in Practice
sections.content: To keep your brain in shape, it’s better to drink water regularly throughout the day rather than only when thirst appears. Keep a bottle nearby, take small sips during breaks, and make sure to drink before tasks that require focus. This simple habit can help you maintain energy, mental clarity, and productivity.

title: Why Is the Brain So Sensitive to Water?

sections.content: We often think of water as just a “filler” for the body. In reality, it plays a central role in how the brain works. It helps brain cells maintain their shape and volume, supports blood flow that delivers oxygen and nutrients, and keeps the water–electrolyte balance stable so neurons can transmit signals effectively.

sections.subtitle: What Happens with Deficiency
sections.content: When fluids decrease, the brain literally changes its shape. MRI scans show that brain tissue can temporarily “shrink.” Blood flow slows, electrolyte balance is disrupted, and neurons become less efficient.

sections.subtitle: How It Feels
sections.content: Imagine music recorded at lower quality. The melody is still there, but the clarity and richness are gone. The same happens with the brain: thinking doesn’t disappear, but focus and speed decline.

sections.subtitle: What This Means for Us
sections.content: Even mild dehydration can affect cognitive functions. To keep your brain sharp, it’s important not to wait for strong thirst signals — instead, drink small amounts regularly throughout the day.
